Notes of Bayesian network (class one)

Course Info:
  • Course Name: Probabilistic Graphical Models
  • Processor: Karen Hovsepian

Example of Bayesian Networks

Distribution of Intelligence: H:(High) A:(Average) L:(Low)

Distribution of Difficulty: L:(Low) H:(High)

Distribution of SAT given by Intelligence: H:(High) M:(Middem) L:(Low)

Distribution of Grade given by Intelligence and Difficulty: H:(High) M:(Middem) L:(Low)

Distribution of Letter given by Grade: G:(Good) A:(Average) B:(Bad)

Distribution of Job given by SAT and Letter: Y:(yes) N:(No)

Marginal Distributions 1

means probability distribution of X for every value of X

which means:

total = 0
for each X in (sum):
    total += P(X)
total == 1 (True)
